messages.content:
I only have one question
Will there be playable musical Instruments ?
its not a no, but currently theyre worried about being able to do so because of audio networking and desync between players with that

referenced_message.content:
I only have one question
Will there be playable musical Instruments ?

messages.content: Yeah. That kind of tech is fascinating. But also super non-trivial. Multiplayer gaming is all one big illusion where everyone's playing in parallel universes that keep telling eachother what happened seconds ago and everyone is constantly playing a game of catchup with everyone else's version of events.

referenced_message.content: its not a no, but currently theyre worried about being able to do so because of audio networking and desync between players with that

messages.content: Wouldn´t help If the music could be heard only by a smaller number of players? Like having It have radius or only the party members could hear It and so on?

referenced_message.content: Yeah. That kind of tech is fascinating. But also super non-trivial. Multiplayer gaming is all one big illusion where everyone's playing in parallel universes that keep telling eachother what happened seconds ago and everyone is constantly playing a game of catchup with everyone else's version of events.

messages.content: No, it's really about the timing. People are very, very sensitive to the timing of musical notes. If your ping is 80 ms and someone else's ping is 80 ms, it could be 160 ms for the note you hit to *start* playing. So if you're both trying to time everything together, there's actual a 160+ ms delay *both ways*.

referenced_message.content: Wouldn´t help If the music could be heard only by a smaller number of players? Like having It have radius or only the party members could hear It and so on?

messages.content: Sea of Thieves have a System for Music which is great. Sure there are 'pre scripted' Events. But the Server-Client communication is well so that when people join they just add another line of music to the already played Track. So its not 'that hard'. Only if you would make it completly played by the players itself.

referenced_message.content: No, it's really about the timing. People are very, very sensitive to the timing of musical notes. If your ping is 80 ms and someone else's ping is 80 ms, it could be 160 ms for the note you hit to *start* playing. So if you're both trying to time everything together, there's actual a 160+ ms delay *both ways*.

messages.content: Right. It's not impossble or unfeasible. But it is not as simple as letting people press a key to make a sound. No one would be happy with that version of it.

referenced_message.content: Sea of Thieves have a System for Music which is great. Sure there are 'pre scripted' Events. But the Server-Client communication is well so that when people join they just add another line of music to the already played Track. So its not 'that hard'. Only if you would make it completly played by the players itself.

messages.content:
I also dont think this is economical interesting.

But lets get into the theory:
You have 10 Instruments. and 10 Songs in the Game you can buy/learn.  You need a 'song line' for the instrument to record and if another player in a radius of x-metres joins the 'Music-Play' and he has the track learned he can join the Musical-Group.

Just by this you have 100 different SKills you could learn.

Its a concept which is also affordable to develop in a game and not too hard. Also giving Content for the players

referenced_message.content: Right. It's not impossble or unfeasible. But it is not as simple as letting people press a key to make a sound. No one would be happy with that version of it.

messages.content: Sure, that sounds like a sensible starting point for such a system, frankly. "Affordable" is a very context sensitive qualifier though. It all comes down to priorities, too. It's not merely "do we make a music playing feature" or not, it's choosing to do it versus something else, and the many many many knock on effects. Maybe a naive implementation ends up annihilating server performance? What if all the network traffic for that ends up doubling server costs in practice? What about people intentionally being a noise nuisance to others? This just a tiny slice of the amount that has to go into making a thoughtful, quality, cozy welcoming world for everyone.

referenced_message.content:

messages.content: If you have a setting that allows players to set limits on who they hear for instruments, that will help. All instruments, friends only, etc.

referenced_message.content: Sure, that sounds like a sensible starting point for such a system, frankly. "Affordable" is a very context sensitive qualifier though. It all comes down to priorities, too. It's not merely "do we make a music playing feature" or not, it's choosing to do it versus something else, and the many many many knock on effects. Maybe a naive implementation ends up annihilating server performance? What if all the network traffic for that ends up doubling server costs in practice? What about people intentionally being a noise nuisance to others? This just a tiny slice of the amount that has to go into making a thoughtful, quality, cozy welcoming world for everyone.

messages.content: Maybe, but now that's a new set of features too - where does that UI show up? What about blocked players? What about muted players? What kind of friction is there to quickly muting? Does the feature become mostly useless for 99% of people if most of them disable it in the first week due to trolls?

referenced_message.content: If you have a setting that allows players to set limits on who they hear for instruments, that will help. All instruments, friends only, etc.

messages.content: As to where, if you have it in a game settings/preferences/options section under sounds, it could be set to music allowed: None/friends only/non muted/all or something similar. Open that setting window, change it to suit the moment.

referenced_message.content: Maybe, but now that's a new set of features too - where does that UI show up? What about blocked players? What about muted players? What kind of friction is there to quickly muting? Does the feature become mostly useless for 99% of people if most of them disable it in the first week due to trolls?

messages.content: FWIW: I'm asking these questions rhetorically. Mostly I'm making the point that said feature involves a lot more than one might think compared to "press button, play sound in multiplayer game", and as a general game dev bit of insight, that's why a seemingly simple feature can be far more complicated to develop. But this is true with practically everything. So we're doing these kind of "how do we do X, what else would it need, what else *wouldn't* we be doing because we spent this time doing X?" all the time.
